contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "was with him" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "God supported him" or "God helped him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: God was with him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "sang loudly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: raised their voices

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "has done exactly what he said he would do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: has carried out the word that he had said

contextId.occurrenceNote: "you who have kept your promise to your servant David my father." To keep a promise is an idiom that means to do what one has promised. Alternate translation: "you who have done what you promised your servant David my father" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: you who have kept with your servant David my father, what you promised him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a request. To carry out what one has said is an idiom meaning to do what one has said. Alternate translation: "please do what you have promised" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: carry out what you have promised

contextId.occurrenceNote: To "listen" is an idiom for responding to prayer. Alternate translation: "please honor their prayer" or "please answer their prayer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: please listen from the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idioms "with all their heart" means "completely" and "with all their soul" means "with all their being." These two phrases have similar meanings. Alternate translation: "completely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with all their heart and with all their soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "kept the dedication" is an idiom meaning "celebrated the dedication." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: they kept the dedication of the altar

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "he successfully finished" or "he caused to be done successfully (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he successfully carried out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being called by God's name is an idiom meaning belonging to God. Alternate translation: "who belong to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: who are called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "she was completely amazed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: there was no more breath in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "every year" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: year after year

contextId.occurrenceNote: To "stand before" is an idiom for serving the king in his presence. Alternate translation: "the old men who counseled Solomon" or "the old men who attended to Solomon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the old men who had stood before Solomon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom and can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "God caused things to happen like this" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: it was a turn in events brought about by God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "carry out his word" means to do what he had said he would do. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: that Yahweh might carry out his word

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "see to" is an idiom meaning to take care of something, and "house" is a metonym for David's lineage of power and prestige. Alternate translation: "Now take care of your own kingdom, descendant of David" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Now see to your own house, David

contextId.occurrenceNote: "choice men who were soldiers." The phrase "chosen men" is an idiom that refers to elite soldiers who were skilled in battle. Alternate translation: "of the best soldiers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: chosen men who were soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: "Yahweh spoke this message ... and he said" or "Yahweh spoke these words ... and he said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the word of Yahweh came ... saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: To "drive away" is an idiom that means to forcefully cause someone to leave. Alternate translation: "Jeroboam and his sons had forced them to leave" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Jeroboam and his sons had driven them away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that he married her. Alternate translation: "Rehoboam married Maacah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Rehoboam took Maacah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means marched against or attacked. Alternate translation: "came to attack" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: came up against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: "Yahweh spoke this message ... and he said" or "Yahweh spoke these words ... and he said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the word of Yahweh came ... saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means marched against or attacked. See how you translated this in [2 Chronicles 12:2](../12/02.md). Alternate translation: "came to attack" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: came up against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that they thoroughly defeated them, or that they killed very many of the soldiers. Alternate translation: "thoroughly defeated them" or "slaughtered many of their soldiers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: killed them with great slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "took ... wives" means that he married. Alternate translation: "he married fourteen women" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he took fourteen wives for himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom which means that the spirit of God influenced Azariah and enabled him to prophesy. Alternate translation: "The Spirit of God gave Azariah the ability to prophesy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The Spirit of God came on Azariah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is an idiom that refers to a person who travels anywhere away from home. Alternate translation: "for the person who traveled anywhere" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: for him who traveled away, nor for him who traveled to here

contextId.occurrenceNote: Together, these two phrases form an idiomatic expression that refers to a person's entire being. Alternate translation: "with all their beings" or "wholeheartedly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with all their heart and with all their soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "with all their heart" means "with complete devotion." Alternate translation: "with complete devotion" or "wholeheartedly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: with all their heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the whole period of time that Asa lived. Alternate translation: "the whole time that he lived" or "throughout his whole life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: all his days

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Here Asa speaks of himself to represent himself along with his army. Alternate translation: "not attack me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: leave me alone

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "from the first thing that he did to the last thing that he did" or "everything he did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: from first to last

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "was with" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "God supported him" or "God helped him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh was with Jehoshaphat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the way a person lives and conducts himself is spoken of as if it were walking. For most of David's life he lived righteously and followed Yahweh closely. Alternate translation: "lived in the first ways of his father David" or "lived righteously as has father David had done in his earlier years" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: walked in the first ways of his father

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "walked" is used here as an idiom. Alternate translation: "followed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: walked in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoshaphat is stating his allegiance to Ahab. Alternate translation: "I offer myself and my soldiers to you to use in any way you want" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like you, and my people are like your people

contextId.occurrenceNote: "as surely as Yahweh is alive." The people use this expression to show that what they say next is certainly true. This is a way of making a solemn promise. Alternate translation: "I solemnly swear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: As Yahweh lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they were standing beside him on his left side and his right side. Alternate translation: "by his right side and by his left side" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: on his right hand and on his left

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the heart represents the will. Jehoshaphat's will is spoken of as being fixed or immovable, which means having an unchanging intention to seek God. Alternate translation: "firmly decided" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: fixed your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh was aware of what the judges decided or 2) Yahweh would hold the judges accountable for their decisions or 3) Yahweh would help and guide them in their decisions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: he is with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "see" is used here as an idiom to add emphasis to what is said next. They could not see the army in Hazezon Tamar from where they were speaking. Alternate translation: "They are already in Hazezon Tamar" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: See, they are in Hazezon Tamar

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "determined himself to seek" or "devoted himself to seek" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: set himself to seek

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "see" here is used as an idiom to emphasize what is said next. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: See how

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom which means that the spirit of God influenced Jahaziel and enabled him to prophesy. See how you translated this in [2 Chronicles 15:1](../15/01.md) (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the Spirit of Yahweh came on

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to go and meet the enemy army for battle. Alternate translation: "march against" or "go to battle against" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: go down against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to go and meet the enemy army for battle. Alternate translation: "March out against" or "Go to battle against" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Go out against

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "fallen to the ground" is an idiomatic way to say that "they were dead." Alternate translation: "they were all dead on the ground" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: they were dead, fallen to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: "with Jehoshaphat leading them." The phrase "in their lead" is an idiom. King Jehoshaphat was in front of the whole army as they went back to Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Jehoshaphat in their lead

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the city of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: city of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: To "rise up over" something is an idiom that means to control it. Alternate translation: "taken complete control over his father's kingdom" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: risen up over his father's kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means he followed their example. See how you translated this in [2 Chronicles 20:32](../20/32.md). Alternate translation: "followed the example" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: walked in the ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means he followed their example. See how you translated this in [2 Chronicles 20:32](../20/32.md). Alternate translation: "followed the example" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: walked in the ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "struck" is an idiom that means Yahweh caused him to be sick. Alternate translation: "Yahweh caused him to suffer from an incurable disease in his intestines" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh struck him in his intestines with an incurable disease

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to a set or appointed time. Alternate translation: "in the proper time" or "when the time was right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: in due time

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "walked in the ways" is an idiom that means he followed Ahab's example. See how you translated this in [2 Chronicles 20:32](../20/32.md). Alternate translation: "He also followed the example" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: He also walked in the ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "at all times" or 2) "wherever he goes." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: when he comes in and when he goes out

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means "as long as Jehoiada, the priest, was alive." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: all the days of Jehoiada, the priest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to the lifespan of Jehoiada. Alternate translation: "for as long as Jehoiada lived" or "throughout the lifetime of Jehoiada" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: for all the days of Jehoiada

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he lived a long time. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: was full of days

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom which means that the Spirit of God influenced Zechariah and enabled him to prophesy. See how you translated a similar phrase in [2 Chronicles 15:1](../15/01.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The Spirit of God came on Zechariah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase "whole heart" is an idiom that means "completely." Alternate translation: "but not completely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: but not with a whole heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "struck down" is an idiom that means they killed them. Alternate translation: "killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: struck down

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means they would both be there in person, rather than communicating through messages or other people. Alternate translation: "meet each other in person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: meet each other face to face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means he had become proud. Alternate translation: "you have become proud" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: your heart has lifted you up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means they were both at the battle in person, rather than only sending other people to fight. See how you translated a similar phrase in [2 Chronicles 25:17](../25/17.md). Alternate translation: "met each other in person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: met each other face to face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "turn away" is an idiom that means he no longer obeyed Yahweh. Alternate translation: "stopped obeying Yahweh" or "started to disobey Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: turned away from following Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to a mighty warrior. Alternate translation: "a mighty warrior" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: a powerful man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that this man was the king's assistant who was second in command. Alternate translation: "who was the king's second in command" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: who was next to the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "stood up against" is an idiom that means to confront or to oppose. Alternate translation: "confronted those who came back from the war" or "opposed those who came back from the war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: stood up against those who came back from the war

contextId.occurrenceNote: Taking a city is an idiom that means to conquer or to capture the city. Alternate translation: "The Philistines captured Beth Shemesh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: They took Beth Shemesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "fallen by the sword" means to die in battle. The word "sword" represents the soldiers, who used swords as their primary weapons. Alternate translation: "our fathers have died in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: our fathers have fallen by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "to stand in his presence" or 2) this is an idiom that means to serve a person of high rank. Alternate translation: "to serve him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: to stand before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "arose" is an idiom that means that the Levites began to act. Alternate translation: "the Levites began to work" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the Levites arose

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that something is organized. Here it refers to the priestly service beginning in the temple again. Alternate translation: "was restored" or "began again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: was set in order

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the most southern and most northern parts of Israel. By referring to them this way, the writer emphasizes that all of Israel was included. Alternate translation: "from Beersheba in the south to Dan in the north" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: from Beersheba to Dan

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "carry out the command" is an idiom meaning to do what was commanded. Alternate translation: "to obey the command" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: to carry out the command

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "kept the festival" is a idiom meaning to participate in the festival or celebrate the festival. Alternate translation: "celebrate the festival" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: kept the Festival of Unleavened Bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "over" is an idiom that means to be in charge of. Alternate translation: "the official in charge of everyone who served in the house of God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the official over the house of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "under" is an idiom that means to be under someone's authority. Alternate translation: "Eden ... assisted Kore in the cities of the priests" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Under him were Eden ... in the cities of the priests

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings for "kings" are 1) this is an idiom that refers to the one king of Assyria. Alternate translation: "the king of Assyria" or 2) this may refer to the king and his other leaders. Alternate translation: "the king and the other leaders of Assyria" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: the kings of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "place over" means to put in charge of. "He put military commanders in charge of the people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: He placed military commanders over the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "lifted up" is an idiom that means to honor. Also, "in the eyes" is a metaphor that represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "the people of all the nations honored him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he was lifted up in the eyes of all nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "became the next king" or "became the king of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: king in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "killed him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: put him to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "became the next king" or "became the king of Judah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: king in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "They have gathered all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: They have emptied out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word is used here as an idiom to draw the listener's attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: "Listen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: See

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "with all his heart" means "completely" and "with all his soul" means "with all his being." These two phrases have similar meanings. Alternate translation: "with all his being" or "with all his energy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: with all his heart and all his soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "accept the terms of the covenant" or "promise to obey the covenant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: stand by the covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "observed the Passover" or "celebrated the Passover" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: kept the Passover

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: "was observed" or "was celebrated" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: was kept

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "removed him at Jerusalem" means that he caused him no longer to be king in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: "The king of Egypt removed him from being king in Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: The king of Egypt removed him at Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to things that he did for which people could accuse him of wrong. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "what people found against him" or "things that he did for which people could accuse him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: what was found against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "followed the ... practices" means to do those things. Alternate translation: "they did the disgusting things that the nations did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: they followed the disgusting practices of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that nobody could do anything to prevent what happened. Alternate translation: "there was no way to avoid it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: there was no help for it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom "brought on them" means to cause to attack with his army. Alternate translation: "God caused the king of the Chaldeans to attack them, and he" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: God brought on them the king of the Chaldeans, who
